Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.description: Common rust is a fungal disease that affects corn, leading to pustules on leaves that can reduce crop yield.
symptoms: Small, reddish-brown pustules on leaves
Pustules releasing orange to brown spores
Leaves yellowing and drying prematurely
treatment: Apply fungicides like azoxystrobin or mancozeb
Remove and destroy infected leaves
Improve field drainage and air circulation
prevention: Rotate crops to reduce pathogen buildup

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.description: Gray leaf spot is a fungal disease that causes rectangular, grayish lesions on corn leaves, leading to reduced photosynthesis.
symptoms: Small, tan spots on leaves that expand into long, grayish lesions
Leaf tissue turning necrotic and dry
Reduced plant vigor and lower yields
treatment: Use fungicides like propiconazole or strobilurins
Remove infected plant debris
Ensure proper plant spacing for airflow

Pepper,_bell___healthy.description: Healthy bell pepper plants exhibit strong growth with lush green leaves and an abundance of flowers and fruit.
symptoms: Deep green, glossy leaves
Strong, upright stems
Abundant flowering and fruit production
treatment: Ensure consistent watering and fertilization
Monitor for pests and diseases regularly
Prune weak or damaged branches to promote growth
prevention: Rotate crops each season to maintain soil health

Corn_(maize)___healthy.description: Healthy corn plants grow tall and strong with vibrant green leaves and well-formed ears.
symptoms: Tall, sturdy stalks with deep green leaves
Well-developed ears with full kernels
Strong root system and resistance to lodging
treatment: Maintain regular watering and fertilization
Monitor for pests and apply treatments as needed
Remove weeds to reduce competition for nutrients
prevention: Rotate crops to prevent disease buildup
Ensure proper spacing to allow adequate sunlight and airflow

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.description: Northern leaf blight is a fungal disease affecting corn, causing large, elongated lesions on leaves and reducing grain production.
symptoms: Large, cigar-shaped grayish-green lesions on leaves
Lesions turning brown and expanding
Severe infections leading to premature leaf death
treatment: Apply fungicides such as azoxystrobin or propiconazole
Remove and destroy infected plant material
Improve air circulation by managing plant density
prevention: Rotate crops to break disease cycles
Use proper field management practices to reduce humidity

Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot is a disease that causes dark, water-soaked lesions on pepper leaves and fruit, leading to defoliation and reduced yield.
symptoms: Small, dark spots on leaves with yellow halos
Lesions coalescing into larger necrotic areas
Blister-like lesions on fruit reducing market quality
treatment: Apply copper-based bactericides
Remove and destroy infected plants
Improve air circulation and reduce leaf wetness
prevention: Rotate crops to prevent bacterial buildup

Potato___Early_blight.description: Early blight is a fungal disease affecting potatoes, causing brown lesions on leaves and tubers, leading to yield loss.
symptoms: Small, dark spots with concentric rings on lower leaves
Yellowing and wilting of affected leaves
Brown sunken lesions on tubers
treatment: Use fungicides like chlorothalonil or mancozeb
Remove and destroy infected plant material
Avoid overhead watering
prevention: Ensure proper plant spacing for airflow

Potato___Late_blight.description: Late blight is a devastating fungal disease that affects potatoes, causing rapid plant decline and tuber rot.
symptoms: Dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves
White, fuzzy fungal growth on leaf undersides
Brown, sunken lesions on tubers leading to rot
treatment: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or copper-based products
Remove infected plants immediately
Improve air circulation and reduce leaf wetness
prevention: Rotate crops to prevent disease buildup
Avoid planting potatoes in areas with previous late blight infections

Potato___healthy.description: A healthy potato plant exhibits strong growth, dark green leaves, and no signs of disease or pest damage.
symptoms: Vibrant, dark green leaves
Strong and sturdy plant structure
Healthy tuber formation with no signs of rot
treatment: Maintain proper watering and fertilization schedules
Monitor regularly for early signs of disease
Remove any damaged or dead plant material
prevention: Ensure good soil health and proper drainage

Tomato___Late_blight.description: Late blight is a severe fungal disease that affects tomato and potato plants, often causing rapid plant decline.
symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on leaves
Dark, irregular spots on stems and fruit
Wilting and yellowing of affected leaves
treatment: Apply fungicides such as copper sulfate or chlorothalonil
Remove and destroy affected plant material
Ensure proper spacing to improve air circulation

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.description: Leaf mold is a fungal disease that primarily affects the foliage of tomatoes, leading to reduced photosynthesis and growth.
symptoms: Yellowish spots on upper sides of leaves
Fuzzy, olive-green fungal growth on the undersides of leaves
Premature leaf drop
treatment: Use fungicides like sulfur or neem oil
Prune infected leaves and remove debris
Increase airflow and avoid overhead watering
prevention: Remove fallen leaves and plant debris
Use drip irrigation to avoid wetting foliage

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot is a disease that affects tomato plants, causing dark lesions with yellow halos on leaves and fruit, leading to defoliation and reduced fruit quality.
symptoms: Small, dark spots with yellow halos on leaves
Lesions on fruit with sunken, water-soaked areas
Premature leaf drop and reduced fruit yield
treatment: Apply copper-based bactericides
Remove and destroy infected plant material
Avoid overhead irrigation to reduce leaf wetness
prevention: Practice crop rotation to avoid bacterial buildup
Sanitize tools and equipment to prevent disease spread

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Septoria leaf spot is a fungal infection that causes spots on tomato leaves, leading to premature defoliation.
symptoms: Small, dark spots with gray centers on lower leaves
Yellow halos around the lesions
Leaves turning yellow and dropping prematurely
treatment: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or copper-based products
Remove infected leaves immediately
Improve plant spacing for better air circulation

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.description: Spider mites are tiny pests that cause significant damage to tomato plants by feeding on plant cells, leading to stippling and leaf damage.
symptoms: Yellow speckling or stippling on leaves
Leaves becoming brittle and dropping
Presence of fine webbing on the underside of leaves
treatment: Use miticides like insecticidal soap or neem oil
Spray plants with a strong jet of water to dislodge mites
Encourage natural predators like ladybugs
prevention: Regularly inspect plants for early signs of mites
Keep plants well-watered to reduce stress

Tomato___Target_Spot.description: Target spot is a fungal disease that causes dark, concentric-ring spots on tomato leaves, reducing plant vigor.
symptoms: Small, round lesions with dark concentric rings
Lesions surrounded by yellow halos
Leaves curling and dropping prematurely
treatment: Apply fungicides like copper-based or mancozeb products
Remove affected leaves to reduce spread
Improve air circulation by spacing plants appropriately
prevention: Rotate crops to reduce disease buildup

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.description: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV) is a viral disease that causes yellowing, curling, and stunting in tomatoes.
symptoms: Yellowing and curling of leaves
Stunted plant growth
Deformed flowers and fruit
treatment: There is no cure for TYLCV, but remove and destroy infected plants
Control whiteflies, which transmit the virus, with insecticides
Practice proper sanitation and remove plant debris
prevention: Avoid planting tomatoes in areas with a history of TYLCV

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV) is a viral disease that causes mottled yellow and green leaves, reducing tomato yield and quality.
symptoms: Mottled yellow and green pattern on leaves
Stunted growth and deformed fruit
Leaf curling and distortion
treatment: There is no cure for ToMV, but remove and destroy infected plants
Use resistant tomato varieties
Disinfect tools and equipment to prevent spread
prevention: Use virus-free seeds and resistant varieties
Control aphid populations, which can spread the virus
Practice crop rotation and remove infected plants

Tomato___healthy.description: Healthy tomato plants exhibit vigorous growth and produce strong, green leaves, with no visible signs of disease or pests.
symptoms: Bright green, undamaged leaves
Healthy, strong plant growth
Vibrant flowers and fruit production
treatment: Maintain regular watering and fertilization schedules
Monitor for pests and diseases regularly
Prune dead or diseased branches promptly
prevention: Ensure good soil health and proper drainage
Provide ample space for growth and airflow

Tomato___Early_blight.description: Early blight is a fungal disease that affects tomato plants, causing dark, concentric lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit. It leads to premature leaf drop and reduced yield.
symptoms: Small, dark spots with concentric rings on older leaves
Lesions on stems that can cause the plant to wilt
Dark spots on fruit with sunken, decayed areas
treatment: Apply fungicides, such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb
Remove and destroy infected plant material
Improve air circulation and reduce moisture on leaves
prevention: Rotate crops to reduce fungal buildup
Water at the base of the plant to keep leaves dry
